skill.name: epistemic-checkpoint
skill.description:
Force verification before answering questions involving versions, dates, status, or "current"
state. Prevents hallucinations at the REASONING level by checking assertions.yaml and WebSearch
before forming beliefs. Triggers on software versions, release status, dates, and package versions.

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill with no code execution capabilities. Only provides behavioral guidelines for Claude to follow when answering version and date questions. No scripts, network calls, file writes, or external command execution.

content.user_title: Verify version and date claims before answering
content.value_statement: AI assistants often provide outdated information about software versions and release dates because their training data is stale. This skill forces verification through assertions.yaml and WebSearch before forming beliefs, preventing hallucinations at the reasoning level.
actual_capabilities: Forces verification of software versions before answering
Checks assertions.yaml for local ground truth
Uses WebSearch to verify against official documentation
Identifies common danger patterns that indicate uncertainty
limitations: Does not execute any tools directly
Does not track real-time version changes
Does not provide built-in citation system
Only activates when user explicitly requests verification

use_cases.title: Verify .NET version claims
use_cases.description: Check if .NET 10 is LTS or preview before recommending features based on version

use_cases.title: Validate release status
use_cases.description: Confirm React, Node, or Python versions and statuses from official sources

use_cases.title: Prevent reasoning errors
use_cases.description: Stop hallucinations at the source by verifying facts before forming beliefs

prompt_templates.title: Check Single Version
prompt_templates.prompt: Check if .NET 10 is LTS or preview

prompt_templates.title: Verify Release Status
prompt_templates.prompt: What is the current status of React 19 and when was it released

prompt_templates.title: Compare Versions
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare Python 3.12 and 3.13 versions and release dates

prompt_templates.title: Validate User Claims
prompt_templates.prompt: The user says they are using .NET 8. Verify if it is still LTS supported

output_examples.input: Check if .NET 10 is LTS or preview

best_practices: Always specify exact versions instead of using "current" or "latest"
Check multiple official sources for version and status confirmation
State your source explicitly when providing version information
anti_patterns: Assuming version information is accurate without verification
Using "pretty sure" or "I remember" as basis for version claims
Trusting user-provided version information without independent verification

faq.question: Does this skill work with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes, it supports all three AI tools and activates whenever version or date verification is needed

faq.question: What software versions does it check?
faq.answer: .NET, Node, Python, React, and any software where version accuracy matters for answers

faq.question: How does verification work?
faq.answer: First checks assertions.yaml, then uses WebSearch on official documentation sites

faq.question: Is my data sent anywhere?
faq.answer: No. This is a prompt-based skill that only instructs verification behavior without making network calls directly

faq.question: Why does it reference assertions.yaml?
faq.answer: assertions.yaml stores verified local facts for your workspace, providing trusted ground truth

faq.question: How is this different from other fact-checking skills?
faq.answer: It focuses specifically on preventing reasoning-level hallucinations about versions and dates before beliefs form
